description: Learned borrowing from Latin sīc (“thus, so”).

entries.meaning: Thus; thus written; used to indicate, for example, that text is being quoted as it is from the source.
examples: Joseph Wright, his predecessor in the chair, called him ‘a firstrate Scholar and a kind of man who will easily make friends’ at Oxford (quoted, sic, in E.M. Wright, The Life of Joseph Wright (1932), p. 483).

verbs.description: sic (third-person singular simple present sics, present participle siccing, simple past and past participle sicced)

entries.meaning: To mark with a bracketed sic.

verbs.description: sic (third-person singular simple present sics, present participle siccing, simple past and past participle sicced)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To incite an attack by, especially a dog or dogs.
examples: He sicced his dog on me!

entries.meaning: (transitive) To set upon; to chase; to attack.
